Abstract
The complexities and non-linearities embedded in the Earth Orientation Parameter
(EOP) - inclusive of polar motion, precision, nutation, and UT1 - have always made
their accurate prediction a challenging endeavor in space engineering. EOPs hold a
paramount role in representing the Earth’s rotational variations against space-fixed
reference frames. Such rotational shifts are driven by the complex interaction of the

solid Earth, oceans, and atmospheric components, resulting in transfers of angular
momentum. Given this backdrop, this Master’s thesis proposes a novel approach to
predict EOPs, harnessing the power of Machine Learning (ML), specifically Long
Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks.
Initially, a comprehensive evaluation was carried out on a range of ML models
such as Support Vector Regression (SVR), Random Forests (RF), and Multi Layer

Perceptron (MLP), gauging their performance in forecasting the five crucial EOP
components over multiple time horizons - 1, 5, 10, 20, 40, and 90 days. Following
these preliminary analyses, the LSTM model was introduced into the research,
renowned for its competency in handling temporal data, recognising intricate time-
based patterns and preserving information over extensive sequences. The LSTM
model was trained and tested using the extensive IERS EOP 14 C04 (IAU2000A)

time-series dataset. The results revealed its superior performance over the initial
models, demonstrating its exceptional capability in understanding and predicting
the complex, non-linear behaviour of EOPs. The scope of this research encompasses
the definition of various use-cases and constraints, bearing in mind mission types,
satellite design requirements, and types of EOP performance simulations.
The validation procedure was undertaken in line with the European Space Agency

(ESA) accuracy standards and utilised CONT14 data supplied by International Earth
Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS). The success of the validation process
confirms the proficiency of the LSTM model in generating precise simulation results,
even at the nascent design stage. Moreover, the model furnishes accurate pointing
performance outcomes such as position knowledge, attitude knowledge, pointing
accuracy, and pointing stability, adhering to ESA’s stringent requirements.

In conclusion, this Master’s thesis signifies a contribution to the intersection of
ML and space engineering, demonstrating the LSTM’s effectiveness in accurately
predicting EOPs. It lays a robust foundation for wider application and exploration
of LSTM networks in intricate space engineering tasks, thereby setting the stage for
advanced EOP prediction systems and fostering innovative research in this domain.

1. Introduction
1.1
Background and Motivation
The Earth Orientation Parameters (EOP) are a set of five angles: Polar Motion
(PM) represented by xp and yp, phase of rotation (UT1-UTC), and Celestial Polar
Offsets (CPO) denoted as dX and dY. The PM, which has an annual motion and
Chandlerian-free wobble with a period of 433 days, is the motion of the Earth’s
pole relative to the International Terrestrial Reference System (ITRS). The phase of

rotation, known as UT1-UTC, represents the difference between the fundamental
form of Universal Time 1 (UT1) and Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). (See Figure
1.1)

(2021))

Figure 1.2 demonstrates how the Earth’s rotation and orientation are influenced by
both gravitational torques exerted by external masses, such as the moon and the
sun, and by geophysical processes like mantle convection in Earth’s interior, mass
redistribution in the atmosphere, oceans, and hydrosphere, and angular momentum
exchange within the Earth-moon system.
Figure 1.2: Earth Motion Factors by NASA

Figure 1.2: Earth Motion Factors by NASA
Traditional geodetic surveillance of these variations hinges on sophisticated techniques.
Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) (Schuh and B¨ohm (2010)) gauges the
Earth’s rotation by measuring the time difference between the arrival of radio waves
from distant quasars to telescopes located thousands of kilometers apart (Schuh and
Behrend (2012)). Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), including systems like

Global Positioning System (GPS) (Kaplan and Hegarty (2017)), Global’naya Navi-
gatsionnaya Sputnikovaya Sistema (GLONASS), Galileo, and BeiDou, continuously
monitor the variable positions of GNSS satellites relative to the Earth to deduce
orientation parameters. Doppler Orbitography and Radiopositioning Integrated by
Satellite (DORIS) provides satellite orbit data by capturing the frequency shift by
the movement of the satellites which is governed by the principle of Doppler’s effect

which was designed and developed by Centre National D’Etudes Spatiales (Saunier
(2023)). Satellite Laser Ranging (SLR) (Combrinck (2010)) involves sending laser
pulses to satellites and measuring their round-trip time to determine the satellites’
orbits and the Earth’s gravitational shape, contributing data to deduce the rotation
parameters. These established methods deliver vital geodetic information enabling
the definition and maintenance of terrestrial and celestial reference frames.

1.2
Objectives of the Thesis
The overarching aim of this thesis is to dissect and harness the predictive power of
Machine Learning (ML) for Earth Orientation Parameter (EOP) forecasting (Schuh
et al. (2002)), with a particular focus on benchmarking against established geodetic

prediction models (Kiani Shahvandi et al. (2023)). This encompasses a multi-faceted
technical exploration that advances from data acquisition to model optimization and
predictive validation (Luzum (2010)). The specific technical objectives are as follows:
Development of a Comprehensive ML Model
The thesis sets out to architect and fine-tune ML model complex enough to encapsu-
late the intricacies embedded in historical EOP datasets. This task involves:

• Curating a rich dataset from reputable EOP data repositories, ensuring a repre-
sentative compilation of variability in Earth’s rotation and orientation.
• Preprocessing and feature engineering to structure the data effectively for ML
consumption, involving noise reduction, normalization, and trend decomposition.
• Exploring various ML architectures, including but not limited to neural networks,
support vector machines, and ensemble methods, to assess their suitability for

temporal and non-linear pattern recognition within EOP data.
• Tuning hyperparameters and regularizing the ML models to enhance their
predictive accuracy and prevent overfitting to the historical data.
Validation of Model Predictions
To establish the ML model as a reliable tool for EOP forecasting, rigorous validation
mechanisms will be employed:
• Implementing cross-validation techniques to evaluate the model’s performance on
unseen data segments, thereby assuring the model’s robustness and repeatability.

4
1. Introduction
• Comparing ML-predicted EOP changes against the outcomes recorded by conven-
tional space-geodetic techniques to quantify improvements in prediction fidelity.
• Utilizing statistical metrics such as Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Ab-
solute Error (MAE), and correlation coefficients to measure prediction accuracy.
Generalizability and Predictive Analysis under Varying Geophysical Conditions
A central thrust of this research is to interrogate the ML model’s extrapolation

prowess across a spectrum of geophysical scenarios:
• Assessing model performance across different temporal scales, from daily up to 3
months predictions, to understand the temporal limits of ML applicability in
EOP forecasting.
• Testing the model under various historical database feeds to gauge its resilience
and adaptability.
• Employing feature importance analysis to identify which aspects of the EOP
dataset most heavily influence the model’s predictions, guiding future enhance-

ments in data collection and preprocessing.
The pursuit of these technical objectives is expected to yield a ML framework that
not only challenges the status quo of EOP prediction but also provides an empirical
foundation for the adoption of ML in geodesy and related scientific disciplines. The
resulting comparative analysis between machine-learned and traditional methods will
underscore the transformative potential that contemporary ML techniques bear on
the field of Earth science.

1.3
State of the Art
In the past, the prediction of Earth Orientation Parameters (EOP) has depended on
the utilization of VLBI (Schuh and B¨ohm (2010)), SLR (Combrinck (2010)), GNSS
(Schuh and B¨ohm (2013)), and other space geodetic techniques. These techniques
enable accurate measurements of the Earth’s rotation and orientation by monitoring
quasars and satellites, allowing for direct observations of variations in EOP (Charlot

et al. (2020)), (Schuh and Behrend (2012)). The IERS has a crucial role in collecting
and distributing these observations, providing a standardized reference for EOP
predictions (Luzum (2010)).
Phenomena like the exchange of angular momentum between the atmosphere and
oceans, as well as variations in the water cycle, can cause disturbances in Earth’s
rotational motion. By integrating these geophysical insights into machine learning

models, either as characteristics or by modifying the model’s structure, it is pos-
sible to enhance the accuracy and resilience of predictions. The works cited are
(Kiani Shahvandi et al. (2023)) and (Luzum (2010)).The Earth Orientation Center
(EOC) of the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS)
publishes daily Earth Orientation Parameters (EOP) values in the C04 series. These
values are important for a range of applications, such as astronomy, geodesy, and

The progression of machine learning (ML) has brought out new approaches in EOP

prediction, which provide a challenge to conventional models by utilizing data-
driven methodologies capable of capturing intricate, non-linear patterns that are
inherent in the EOP time series. Neural networks, specifically LSTM networks,
have demonstrated potential in accurately representing time-based sequences with
extended dependencies, rendering them appropriate for challenges involving the
prediction of EOPs (Dhar et al. (2022)), (Wang et al. (2019)), (Kumar Dubey et al.

(2021)), (Huang et al. (2022)), (Sirisha et al. (2022)) and (Khaira et al. (2020)). The
capacity of machine learning algorithms to acquire knowledge from past data and
apply it to new, unfamiliar data provides a notable benefit in forecasting variations
in EOP across different geophysical conditions (Gou et al. (2023)) and (Albeladi
et al. (2023)).
A notable advancement in the analytical techniques for EOP prediction is the applica-

tion of SSA. SSA has been instrumental in decomposing time series into constituent
components, facilitating a deeper understanding of the underlying dynamics. This
method’s integration into EOP forecasting has enriched the predictive models with
enhanced analytical depth, enabling more nuanced and accurate predictions of EOP
variations (Modiri (2021)).
1.4
Structure of the thesis
This master thesis is organized into eight chapters, each delving into a specific aspect

of predicting (EOPs) using (ML) techniques, with an emphasis on LSTM networks
integrated with SSA.
Chapter 2 reviews the theoretical underpinnings of the Earth’s rotation and orienta-
tion parameters, provides an exposition on the dynamics of these parameters, and
delves into the current state-of-the-art techniques for monitoring EOPs, including
space-geodetic techniques like VLBI. It also surveys the role and evolution of Machine

Learning in the context of EOP prediction, setting the stage for subsequent analyses.
Chapter 3 articulates the research methodology in detail, delineating every step
from data acquisition from the IAU2000A C04 dataset to preprocessing, ML model
selection, parameter tuning, and establishing benchmarks for evaluation. It elucidates
the integration of SSA with LSTM for decomposing and reconstructing the time
series data for enhanced prediction performance.

2.1
Motion of Earth
The Earth’s motion, both in its orbit around the Sun and its rotation on its axis, is
a foundational aspect of our planet’s dynamics, deeply influencing various terrestrial
and celestial phenomena. As the third planet in the solar system, Earth follows an
elliptical orbit around the Sun, completing one revolution annually. This revolution,
coupled with the Earth’s axial tilt of 23.5 degrees relative to its orbital plane, leads

to the cyclical nature of seasons.
Simultaneously, the Earth rotates on its axis, an imaginary line connecting the North
and South Poles, once every 24 hours. This rotation is responsible for the daily cycle
of day and night and contributes to the apparent westward motion of the Sun, Moon,
and stars across the sky. The tilt of the Earth’s axis also means that the Sun’s path,
as observed from Earth, appears to traverse a tilted trajectory relative to this axis.

This phenomenon is what gives us the varying lengths of day and night throughout
the year.
The Earth’s orbital path projects onto the celestial sphere as the ecliptic. The
points where this path intersects the celestial equator are known as the equinoxes.
Conversely, the solstices – the summer solstice around June 21st and the winter
solstice around December 21st – mark the extremes of the Sun’s apparent path on
the celestial sphere.

the celestial sphere.
A critical aspect of Earth’s motion is precession, the gradual shift in the direction of
the Earth’s axis of rotation. Influenced primarily by gravitational forces from the
Sun and the Moon, this slow movement alters the orientation of the Earth’s axis
over a cycle of approximately 26,000 years. This precession movement means that
the celestial poles and equators are not fixed in location but gradually shift, affecting

the celestial coordinates of astronomical objects. As a result, the reference frame for
celestial coordinates, traditionally tied to the position of the vernal equinox. The

8
2. Geodesy Fundamentals and Related Work
commonly used reference frame today is the Equinox J2000.0, which is based on the
equinox and mean equator positions as of January 1, 2000 12:00:00.
Understanding and monitoring Earth’s rotation and orbital movement is crucial for
various scientific and practical applications. It is foundational for timekeeping, navi-
gation, and the establishment of global reference frames. The continuous observation

of these motions provides insights into the interactions between the Earth’s compo-
nents, such as the atmosphere, oceans, and solid Earth, and the internal dynamics
involving the Earth’s core and mantle (Chao et al. (1996)). Today, precise space
geodetic techniques like VLBI (Schuh and Behrend (2012)), SLR/ LLR, GNSS, and
ring laser gyroscopes are employed to measure these movements with high accuracy,
contributing to a comprehensive understanding of Earth’s intricate motions within

the solar system.
2.2
International Celestial Reference System (ICRS)
The International Celestial Reference System (ICRS) as described in IERS Technical
notes by (Petit and Luzum (2010)) is a highly precise and stable celestial coordinate
system that serves as a foundation for modern astronomical observations and data.
It is based on the positions of distant extragalactic objects, primarily quasars, which
are considered to have negligible proper motions, making them ideal for defining a

fixed frame of reference. The ICRS is realized through the ICRF, which provides a
set of precise coordinates for these objects.
The ICRF’s establishment and ongoing refinement are crucial for maintaining the
accuracy of the ICRS. The first realization of the ICRF (ICRF1) (Ma et al. (1998))
was constructed in 1995 using Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) to measure
the positions of 212 defining extragalactic radio sources. The second realization,

ICRF2 (Fey et al. (2015)) introduced in 2009, marked a significant enhancement
in the frame’s precision and stability. It expanded the number of sources to over
3,000, significantly reducing the formal uncertainties in position measurements and
increasing the frame’s overall stability by January 1, 2010.
The International Astronomical Union (IAU) adapted to ICRF3 and has further
enhanced its accuracy by containing 4,536 objects at S and X bands as of January 1,
2019 as shown in the Figure 2.1

2.3
International Terrestrial Reference System (ITRS)
According to (Petit and Luzum (2010)) the ITRS comprises a global framework
designed to define the positions and motions of objects on and near the Earth’s
surface with high precision. It is operationalized through the International Terrestrial

Reference Frame (ITRF), which combines careful determined three-dimensional
coordinates and velocities of points distributed across the Earth’s crust. These points
are anchored at geodetic observatories equipped with sophisticated space geodesy
techniques such as VLBI, SLR, GNSS including GPS, and DORIS. The ITRF’s
construction entails a sophisticated combination of data from these diverse geodetic
techniques, necessitating the establishment of highly precise local ties at co-location

sites to integrate the disparate data streams into a singular, cohesive reference frame.
Over the years, the ITRF has undergone numerous revisions, each iteration marked
by advancements in data quality, network density, and analytical methodologies.
Successive versions, including ITRF88, ITRF2000, ITRF2005, and ITRF2008, have
systematically enhanced the frame’s accuracy and stability. These enhancements
reflect the cumulative improvements in geodetic instrumentation, data processing

techniques, and the expanding global network of geodetic observatories. The evolution
of the ITRF, coordinated by the IERS, underscores a commitment to maintaining
the highest standards of precision and consistency in global terrestrial referencing,
pivotal for a myriad of scientific research and practical applications ranging from
plate tectonics and Earth dynamics studies to precise navigation and environmental
monitoring.

2.4
Earth Orientation Parameter (EOP)
EOP play a crucial role in the precise alignment of terrestrial and celestial reference
frames, essential for high-precision geodetic and astronomical observations. These

10

parameters facilitate the transformation between the ITRS and the Geocentric
Celestial Reference System (GCRS), accounting for the dynamic and complex motion
of the Earth. The EOP consist of five key components: two polar motion coordinates
(xp, yp), the difference in Universal Time (UT1-UTC), and celestial pole offsets
(dX, dY ). These components reflect the Earth’s irregular rotation and orientation in

space, influenced by various geophysical and astronomical factors.
The polar motion (PM), xp and yp, describe the shifting of the Earth’s rotation axis
relative to its surface, encompassing the Chandler wobble with a period of about 433
days and an annual wobble. The UT1-UTC component, a measure of the Earth’s
rotation angle, is vital for timekeeping and navigation, correlating with the length
of the day and affected by factors such as tidal forces and changes in the Earth’s

moment of inertia (Capitaine and Wallace (2006)). CPO, dX and dY , represent
the corrections to the IAU precession-nutation model, accounting for the small but
significant discrepancies between the observed and modeled motion of the celestial
pole, influenced by phenomena such as the Free Core Nutation (FCN) (Dehant and
Mathews (2015)).
The transformation matrix, incorporating these EOP, is mathematically represented
as

providing updated EOP values, essential for a broad spectrum of scientific and
practical applications, including satellite navigation, climate research, and global
telecommunications (Petit and Luzum (2010)).

This motion is crucial for understanding the dynamics of Earth’s rotation and for

2.4.2
Celestial Pole Offsets (CPO)
CPO are critical components in the area of EOPs, playing a significant role in the
accurate transformation of coordinates between the ITRS and the GCRS. These
offsets represent the time-dependent corrections needed to align the conventional
celestial pole with the CIP.

In the context of EOPs, CPOs are denoted as dX and dY . They are part of the
precession/nutation matrix, Q(t), in the transformation equation:
[GCRS] = Q(t) · R(t) · W(t) · [ITRS]
Here, Q(t) specifically accounts for the CPOs, alongside the other matrices R(t) for
Earth’s rotation and W(t) for polar motion (Schuh and B¨ohm (2013)).
The conventional celestial pole’s position is defined by the IAU precession and nutation

models. However, these models do not perfectly represent the actual motion of the
CIP due to various geophysical factors. CPOs dX and dY are introduced to correct
these discrepancies and are shown in Figure 2.4 and 2.5 respectively. These offsets
are essential for accommodating residual errors in the a priori precession/nutation
model and phenomena such as the FCN, which is a resonance effect caused by the
misalignment of the rotation axes of the Earth’s mantle and core.

The FCN manifests as a retrograde motion with a period of about 433 days in
the GCRS and can have significant amplitudes, making precise measurement and
correction through CPOs crucial for maintaining high positioning accuracy. The
IERS provides these offsets, derived from ongoing observations and space geodetic
techniques, such as VLBI.
2.4.3
Universal Time
DUT1 (Delta UT1) is a critical component of Earth Orientation Parameters (EOPs)

and plays a significant role in precision timekeeping and astronomical observations.
It represents the difference between UT1, which is based on the Earth’s rotation,
and UTC, which is a standardized atomic time scale.
UT1 is a form of Universal Time that corrects for variations in the Earth’s rotation
which is the mean solar time. The Earth’s rotation is not uniform due to various
geophysical and astronomical factors, including tidal forces, the movement of the

Earth’s core, and changes in atmospheric pressure. UT1 reflects these irregularities.
UTC, on the other hand, is maintained through a network of highly precise atomic
clocks and is kept within 0.9 seconds of UT1 by the insertion of leap seconds (Nelson
et al. (2001)). This adjustment ensures that UTC remains in close synchronization
with the mean solar time.

3.1
Long Short Term Memory (LSTM)
LSTM is a specialized variant of Recurring Neural Network (RNN) designed to
effectively process sequences of data. Originating from the groundbreaking work in
1997 by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber (1997) and subsequently refined by numerous
researchers, LSTMs have garnered widespread adoption due to their exceptional
performance across a myriad of problems.

performance across a myriad of problems.
One of the critical challenges in sequential data processing is the need to remember
information over long periods. Traditional RNNs often falter in this aspect due to a
phenomenon known as ”vanishing gradients,” where the network loses the ability to
learn connections between events separated by long time intervals.
LSTMs address this challenge with a unique architecture that includes components

called ”gates.” These gates control the flow of information, allowing the network to
retain or discard data as needed. This mechanism enables LSTMs to ”remember”
relevant past information and ”forget” irrelevant data, making them exceptionally
adept at understanding long-range dependencies in the data.

3.2
Autoregressive (AR) Modeling
Autoregressive (AR) models are a fundamental class of models used in time series
analysis, particularly effective in scenarios where successive values in the series are
correlated. These models are especially relevant when predicting time-dependent
phenomena such as EOPs. An AR model predicts future behavior based on past
behavior. It assumes that past values have a linear influence on future values. The

model is essentially a regression of the time series onto itself at previous times.
The general form of an AR model of order p, denoted as AR(p) is:
Yt = c + ϕ1Yt−1 + ϕ2Yt−2 + . . . + ϕpYt−p + εt
(3.9)
Here, Yt is the value of the series at time t, and ϕ1, ϕ2, . . . , ϕp are the coefficients
that measure the influence of each lagged value. c is a constant (intercept) term, and
εt is white noise error. p indicates the number of lagged observations included in the
model.

model.
Dynamics of AR models: In an AR model, each term can be thought of as a
weighted version of past observations. The weights (ϕ coefficients) determine how
much influence each past observation has on the forecast. The order p of the model
defines how far back in the past the model will go to predict the current value. High
ϕ values indicate that the time series is influenced significantly by its past values.

Application in EOP forecasting: AR models are particularly useful for EOP forecast-
ing if the data shows that past orientation parameters significantly influence future
parameters. For instance, if EOP data demonstrates autocorrelation over a specific
number of lags, an AR model of that order could effectively capture this dependence.
Selecting the order of AR Model: The order p is typically determined through
analysis methods like the Partial Autocorrelation Function (PACF), which helps

identify the extent of lagged influence. Overfitting is a risk with higher-order AR
models, so it’s crucial to choose p such that it sufficiently captures the autocorrelation
without being overly complex.
Limitations: AR models assume linearity and may not perform well with non-linear
data. They may not adequately handle time series data with trend and seasonal
components unless appropriately modified or differenced. AR models can be sensitive

to outliers, which can significantly influence the coefficient estimates.

suitable for EOPs.

Model Dynamics: The ARIMA(1,0,0) as suggested by (Khaira et al. (2020))

by its immediate past value. The coefficient ϕ1 plays a crucial role. If ϕ1 is close

a significant influence on the current value. If ϕ1 is close to 0, it implies that
the past value has little to no effect on the current value, reducing the model

to essentially ˆYt = µ. The constant µ adjusts the level around which the series
oscillates. If the mean of the series is zero, then µ might not be included in the
model.
Applicability in EOPs: When applied to EOPs, this model is especially useful if
the data shows a pattern where each value tends to be close to its preceding value,
with slight variations. For instance, if EOP data demonstrates gradual changes
rather than abrupt shifts, the ARIMA(1,0,0) model can effectively capture this

behavior, assuming that each day’s orientation parameter is a slight modification
of the previous day’s parameter.
Limitations: While ARIMA(1,0,0) is powerful in capturing linear relationships
in time series data, it may not be as effective in scenarios where the data exhibits
non-linear patterns, significant seasonal effects, or trends. The model’s simplicity
can be a drawback if the EOP data has complex underlying structures that a
single lag and a constant term cannot adequately capture.

4.1.1
Dataset Overview
The EOP 14 C04 series, curated by the Earth Orientation Parameter (EOP) Product
Center at the Paris Observatory under the auspices of the International Earth
Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS), is a cornerstone dataset for Earth
orientation studies. This dataset is meticulously aligned with the IAU 2000 Precession-
Nutation Model and is consistent with the International Terrestrial Reference Frame

2020 (ITRF2020) Bizouard et al. (2019), offering unparalleled insights into Earth’s
dynamic orientation. The dataset is sampled bi-daily at 12-hour intervals UTC,
providing a dense temporal resolution for detailed analysis.
Each data entry within the EOP 14 C04 series follows a precise format, defined by
the format string, and can be understood as follows:
• Date and Time: The first four integer fields, each 4 characters wide, denote the

Year (YR), Month (MM), Day (DD), and Hour (HH), respectively, providing
the exact timestamp for each measurement.
• Modified Julian Date (MJD): A floating-point field, 10 characters wide with 2
decimal places, offering a continuous count of days that facilitates chronological
analysis across the dataset.
• Pole Coordinates (xp, yp): Two floating-point fields, each 12 characters wide
with 6 decimal places, represent the x and y components of Earth’s polar motion

in arcseconds, indicating the axial tilt and wander.
• UT1-UTC (s): A 12-character wide floating-point field with 7 decimal places,
detailing the difference between Earth-rotation-based Universal Time 1 (UT1)
and Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) in seconds.
• Celestial Pole Offsets (dX, dY ): Adjustments in Earth’s rotational axis ori-
entation relative to the celestial frame are recorded in two 12-character wide
floating-point fields, each with 6 decimal places.

• Rates of Change (xrt”, yrt”): These fields, each 12 characters wide with 6
decimal places, indicate the temporal variations in the pole coordinates, reflecting
dynamic changes in Earth’s orientation.
• Length of Day (LOD) Variation (s): A 12-character wide floating-point field
with 7 decimal places, capturing the variability in Earth’s rotational period,

• Measurement Uncertainties: The dataset also includes uncertainties for each

measurement, denoted by fields such as x Er, y Er, UT1-UTC Er, dX Er, dY

12-character wide floating-point field with 7 decimal places, providing insights

The IERS EOP 14 C04 dataset undergoes rigorous annual data preparation and
daily combination processes as explained by (Bizouard et al. (2019)) to ensure its

accuracy, consistency, and alignment with international reference frames which are
as follows:
Annual Data Preparation:
Each year begins with the selection or update of EOP series, incorporating mea-
surements like UT1-UTC, LOD, and pole coordinates from various space geodetic
techniques. This step ensures a diverse and comprehensive dataset reflective of
Earth’s orientation changes.
Formal uncertainties of EOP values are rescaled to rectify potential inconsistencies

and normalize the dataset, making it more reliable. This involves adjusting the
uncertainties to match the average standard deviation of paired differences within
the selected series.
Additionally, the dataset is rigorously aligned with the current space reference frames,
such as ICRF and ITRF, through a detailed characterization process. This alignment
corrects for network effects and certifies the dataset’s relevance and precision.
Daily Combination Procedure:

Daily Combination Procedure:
The daily integration of selected EOP series into the EOP 14 C04 dataset involves
collecting EOP values with their a priori uncertainties and ensuring series homogeneity
by addressing network instabilities and rescaling uncertainties. Differences with
reference values are calculated and averaged to derive the combined EOP values,
ensuring dataset integrity.

4.2.2.1
Embedding Step
Embedding in Singular Spectrum Analysis (SSA) suggested by (Hyndman and
Athanasopoulos (2018)), Kalarus et al. (2010), Rocco S (2013) and Hassani (2022)) is
a fundamental step that transforms a one-dimensional time series X = (x1, . . . , xN)

32
4. Data
into a multidimensional representation. This process involves creating lagged vectors
X1, . . . , XK from X, where each Xi is a vector containing L consecutive elements of
the original series. The number of resulting vectors K is determined by the window
length L and the length of the original series N such that K = N −L + 1.
The window length L is a crucial parameter in embedding. It defines the length of

each lagged vector and influences the properties of the resulting trajectory matrix.
The choice of L is essential; it needs to strike a balance. If L is too small, it might
not capture essential characteristics of the time series. Conversely, if L is excessively
large, it could create too many lagged vectors, losing the specific dynamics of the
original series.
Different fields have varying approaches to selecting L. In dynamical systems analysis,

for instance, smaller L values are used to calculate correlation dimensions, which
relate to the fractal dimensions of the system’s attractor. Here, L is small relative to
a very large K (K →∞). Conversely, methods like Structural Total Least Squares
(STLS) with Hankel matrix structure often select L = r + 1, where r represents the
estimated rank of the approximation matrix.
In SSA, L should be chosen to be sufficiently large to encapsulate essential dynamics

of the original series within each lagged vector. Larger L values offer the advantage of
treating each lagged vector Xi as an independent series. This enables the exploration
of specific characteristics and dynamics across this set of derived series.
The choice of L is a critical consideration in SSA, impacting how well the resulting
lagged vectors represent the underlying dynamics of the original time series. It’s

essential to balance the trade-off between capturing essential information and avoiding
excessive fragmentation of the data. Detailed discussions on optimal L selection
can be found in specialized literature, allowing practitioners to tailor embedding for
various types of time series analysis.

a significant positive autocorrelation at earlier lags that decreases as time progresses.

The blue shaded area in the autocorrelation plot represents the confidence interval,
usually at 95%, which helps to distinguish significant correlation values from those
that could occur by chance. If the autocorrelation bar for a specific lag exceeds this
blue area, it indicates that the correlation at that lag is statistically significant.
The gradual decrease of the autocorrelation indicates that the xp variable is subject

to prediction based on its previous values, so approaches such as SARIMA or LSTM
can be effective for prediction. The autocorrelation is much stronger at shorter lags,
which can be used to set parameters for time series forecasting models.

Overview of Results
This chapter demonstrates the results of implementing machine learning methodolo-

EOP prediction for xp and yp: This work describes the utilization of LSTM and

6.5.1
Comparison with ESA Benchmarks
When evaluating the accuracy of machine learning models for predicting Earth
Orientation Parameters (EOPs), an important measure for determining success is to
compare the model’s performance with the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) benchmarks
established by the ESA. This section shows a thorough evaluation of the performance
of different models, namely Autoregressive (AR), SARIMA, LSTM, and LSTM

with Singular Spectrum Analysis (LSTM+SSA), in predicting three essential Earth
Orientation Parameters (EOPs): xp, yp, and UT1-UTC.
xp Predictions
The AR model for xp predictions had a successful outcome, with a Mean Absolute
Error (MAE) of 0.13 milliarcseconds (mas) on the 1-day forecast. This result is
significantly above the ESA benchmark of 0.3 mas. The SARIMA model significantly
enhanced the accuracy of the 1-day forecast, obtaining an excellent Mean Absolute

Error (MAE) of 0.07 mas. However, the LSTM model exhibited constraints in
its ability to accurately predict short-term outcomes, as demonstrated by a mean
absolute error (MAE) of 4.44 mas, surpassing the minimum requirement set by the
ESA.
As the time frame of the forecast increases, the LSTM model demonstrates a significant
enhancement in its performance. In the 5-day forecast, the LSTM model had a mean
absolute error (MAE) of 2.16 milliarcseconds (mas), which exceeded the standard set

by the ESA of 1.8 mas. On the other hand, the SARIMA model performed better with
an MAE of 0.7 mas. After 10 days, the LSTM model performed very well, achieving
an MAE of 2.02 mas, which closely matched the ESA benchmark. However, when
the LSTM model was combined with SSA, the performance significantly deviated,
resulting in an MAE of 17.70 mas. This indicates that integrating SSA for this
prediction interval has significant issues. When predicting for extended periods (20,

40, and 90 days), the LSTM model continuously fulfilled the standards set by the ESA.

7. Conclusion
This thesis focused on the utilization of machine learning methodologies, specifically
Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated
Moving Average (SARIMA) models, for predicting Earth Orientation Parameters
(EOPs). The results illustrate the efficiency of these models in predicting parameters
such as xpole, ypole, and UT1 −UTC across different time periods.
For the short-term (1-day) analysis, SARIMA models demonstrated remarkable

efficiency, resulting in low Mean Absolute Error (MAE) values and proving their
ability to accurately capture the short-term seasonality fluctuations in EOP data.
For medium to long-term forecasting, the LSTM model demonstrated high accuracy
in predicting EOPs over periods spanning from 10 to 90 days. This underlines
its ability to effectively handle sequential data and the time-related patterns that
are inherent in EOPs. For short-term forecasts, the SARIMA models accurately

predicted the values for the next day based on the xpole projections. These models
effectively dealt with the complexities of both seasonal and non-seasonal trends in
the EOP data.
For projections ranging from 20 to 90 days, LSTM models consistently demonstrated
reliable performance, frequently surpassing the accuracy standards set by ESA. The
utilization of the LSTM model just for UT1-UTC predictions demonstrated improved

precision throughout a range of time intervals, encompassing both short-term and
long-term forecasts. This emphasizes the model’s flexibility and capacity to adjust
to various forecasting timeframes.
During the two-week CONT14 campaign, the LSTM model demonstrated exceptional
precision by obtaining Mean Absolute Errors (MAEs) that were much lower than the
benchmarks set by the European Space Agency (ESA) for both the xpole and ypole
variables as well as for the UT1-UTC data.

opportunities for accurate Earth Orientation Parameter (EOP) prediction, which

The results and methods presented in this thesis provide the foundation for future
research efforts focused on improving the forecasting of Earth Orientation Param-

alternative machine learning methodologies or create hybrid models that may provide

A.1.4
Prepare Data for UT1-UTC Prediction and Use of Leap Sec-
onds
The preparation of data for predicting UT1-UTC values involves several critical steps,
including the handling of leap seconds, which are crucial for maintaining accurate
timekeeping in astronomical and geodesy applications. The process is outlined below:
1. Data Loading: The UT1-UTC data, along with other relevant measurements,
are loaded from a CSV file containing historical records. This dataset includes
measurements from January 1, 1972, to November 6, 2023.

2. Leap Second Adjustment: Leap seconds are applied to the UT1-UTC data to
account for irregularities in Earth’s rotation. A separate DataFrame is created
to manage these adjustments, with leap seconds being forward-filled to cover all
dates within the range.
3. Data Merging: The UT1-UTC data and leap second adjustments are merged
based on their dates to calculate the corrected UT1-TAI values, which are
essential for the prediction model.

essential for the prediction model.
4. Incorporation of Length of Day (LOD): The LOD measurements are integrated
into the dataset, providing a cumulative time correction. This correction is
then combined with the UT1-TAI values to obtain the final UT1 values used for
training the predictive model.
This preparation process ensures that the data used for training the predictive model
is accurate and reflects the adjustments necessary for precise timekeeping, including

the application of leap seconds and the accumulation of LOD corrections.
A.1.5
Converting Predicted UT1 to UT1-UTC and Model Evalua-
tion
After obtaining the predicted UT1 values, the subsequent step involves adjusting these
predictions to derive the UT1-UTC values. This adjustment necessitates accounting
for time corrections and leap seconds. Subsequently, the model’s accuracy is assessed
by comparing the adjusted predictions against the actual UT1-UTC values, utilizing

the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) as the metric.
Adjusting Predicted UT1 Values
The predicted UT1 values are modified to reflect the necessary time corrections and
the current leap seconds to facilitate their conversion back to UT1-UTC format. The
adjustment process entails:
• Subtracting the cumulative time correction from the predicted UT1 values to
obtain the UT1-TAI values.
• Adding the current leap second value to the UT1-TAI values to convert them
into UT1-UTC values.

Now a day, space tourism in sub-orbital flights has confronted us. In the next few years, the suborbital space-crafts 
will transport payloads and passengers to space. People who may be flying into suborbital space will have a world 
class adventure that will bring a lifetime’s memory. People will experience the weightlessness of few minutes but 
will expose to solar radiation and bombarded with cosmic rays by supernovae and other galactic explosion. Cosmic

Rays are inescapable in space, ripping right through an astronaut damaging the DNA and causing cancer. Galactic 
cosmic rays are one of the most important barriers standing in the way of plans for sub-orbital flights by crewed 
spacecraft. Cosmic rays also pose a threat to electronics with the next level microelectronics which are extremely 
sensitive placed aboard outgoing probes. While the space is full of radiation, the earth’s magnetic fields protect the

planet and people in low earth orbit from the particles. But once the astronaut are expose to high amount of radiation 
with the constant shower of various radioactive particles. This radiation exists in low levels, the longer an astronaut 
is in deep space, the greater the exposure. We can’t precisely trace the cosmic rays as it is bent by magnetic fields 
and it is impossible to control the level of radiations, astronauts are exposed to.

Keywords: Cosmic Rays, Supernovae, Magnetic Field, Solar Radiation 
 
 
1. Introduction  
Suborbital spaceflights offers opportunity to ‘touch’ 
space and experience ‘weightlessness’ by creating 
substantial public interest. But due to the fact that 
radiation exists throughout the universe, originating 
from many sources with varying intensities and 
composition. For a number of radiation effects in the

natural space radiation environment can be classified 
into two populations: all the particles including protons, 
electrons and heavier ions and transient particles which 
are trapped by planetary magnetosphere in ‘belts’, 
which include protons and heavy ions of all elements of 
the periodic table. The Earth’s magnetosphere is 
swamped  by a nearly isotropic flux of cosmic rays. 
 
 
1.1 Effects on human body

1.1 Effects on human body 
Space isn’t an environment we’ve evolved to survive 
in. Let’s say you are lucky enough to have begged 
yourself space flight. As you lie back on your seat 
during the final seconds of countdown, what is expected 
to happen to your body over the coming minutes, hours, 
days or even months? The body feels four times its 
normal weight. Crushed back into the seat, moving your 
arms in increasingly difficult. G-forces push blood into

the feet and we need blood supply to our brain to stay 
conscious. At even relatively low G-force, fighter pilots 
have impaired vision- or “grey out”- as the blood 
pressure to the head drops. One of the first things that 
the astronauts complain about is nausea or vomiting.

2. Material and Methods  
    As we all know that when solar flares [2][3] explode 
from sun’s atmosphere, along with the gigantic burst of 
light in nearly all wavelengths, waves of energetic

particles are accelerated by this event. Mostly protons, 
with a few electrons and heavier elements mixed in, this 
would have been dangerous to humans who are outside 
earth’s protective magnetic shield. In the early days of 
human space flight, scientists were only just beginning 
to understand how solar radiation [4] could affect space, 
and in turn how that radiation could affect humans and 
technology. Radiation, at its most basic, is simply waves

or sub atomic particles that transport energy to another 
entity- whether it is an astronaut or component of 
spacecraft. Particle radiation in space is the main 
concern. Energetic particles are often dangerous to 
humans as a result of they pass all over the skin, 
depositing energy and damaging cells or DNA on the 
manner. This harm will mean associate exaggerated risk 
for cancer later in life or, at its worst, acute radiation 
throughout the mission if the dose of energetic particles

is massive enough. Throughout the entire trip, 
astronauts must be protected from two sources of 
radiation. The first comes from the sun, that frequently 
releases a gradual stream of solar particles, also as 
occasional huge bursts within the wake of big 
explosions, like solar flares and coronal mass ejections, 
on the sun.. These energetic particles area unit the 
majority protons, and, although the sun releases AN 
unfathomably sizable amount of them, the nucleon

unfathomably sizable amount of them, the nucleon 
energy is low enough that they'll the majority be 
physically secure by the structure of the space vehicle. 
The second supply of energetic particles is harder to 
shield. These particles comes from galactic cosmic rays, 
typically called GCRs. These are particles accelerated to 
near the speed of light that shoot into our solar system 
from other stars in the Milky Way or even other 
galaxies. Like solar particles, galactic cosmic rays are

mostly protons. However, some of them are heavier 
elements, ranging from helium up to the heaviest 
elements. These more energetic particles can knock 
apart atoms in the materials they strike, such as in the 
astronaut, the metal walls of a spacecraft , habitat, or 
vehicle, causing sub atomic particles to shower into the 
structure. This secondary radiation, as it is known, can 
reach a dangerous level. There are two ways to shield 
from these higher energy particles and their secondary

radiation: use a lot more mass of traditional space craft 
materials, or use more efficient shielding materials. The 
sheer volume of materials surrounding a structure would 
absorb the energetic particles and their associated 
secondary particle radiation before they could reach the 
astronauts. However, using sheer bulk to protect 
astronauts would be prohibitively expensive, since more 
mass means more fuel required to launch. The best way

to stop particle radiation is by running that energetic 
particle into something that’s a similar size, because 
protons and neutrons are similar in size, one element 
blocks both extremely well hydrogen, which most 
commonly exists as just a single proton and an electron. 
Conveniently, hydrogen, which is the most abundant 
element in the universe, and make up substantial parts 
of some common compounds, such as water and plastics 
like polyethylene.  Engineers could take advantage of

already required mass by processing the astronaut’s 
trash into plastic-filled tiles used to bolster radiation 
protection. Water, already required for the crew, could 
be stored strategically to create a kind of radiation storm 
shelter in the spacecraft or habitat. However, this 
strategy comes with some challenges- the crew would 
need to use the water and then replace it with recycled 
water from the advanced life support systems. 
Polyethylene [5], the same plastic commonly found in

water bottles and grocery bags, also has potential as a 
candidate for radiation shielding. It is very high in 
hydrogen and fairly cheap to produce- however, it’s not 
strong enough to build a large structure, especially a 
spacecraft, which goes through high heat and strong 
forces during launch. And adding polyethylene to a 
mental structure would add quite a bit of mass, meaning 
that more fuel would be required for launch. 
 
3. Theory  
Subatomic particles [6] coming from solar radiation

and cosmic rays are constantly arriving from distant 
stars and galaxies and passing right through us. They 
can cause significant problems and dangers for humans. 
They can also harm our computer run programs as all 
computers run programs using a code of zeroes and 
ones. When a cosmic ray hits a computer chip, it can 
cause a reaction with the silicon, sending the wires over 
their critical voltage. This can flip one of the bits in the 
code from zero to one or one to zero, and suddenly the

code is incorrect. The program now has a “soft error” 
that may cause it to fail.(Fig.4) Soft errors are an on-
going problem for computer engineers, which are more 
effected by cosmic rays. Computers in a spacecraft are 
responsible for navigation and life support, so it is 
essential for accuracy and precision to be maintained 
and for errors not to occur. As like humans require 
protection from cosmic rays to avoid the harmful 
disease-causing effects of radiation computers too

require protection, for those computers currently have 
some software in to search for and fix errors. For this 
we have some radiation shielding materials including 
aluminium, steel, gold and magnets. We can use these 
materials for their cosmic ray shielding ability.  
Alpha particles can be easily stopped by things like 
skin or paper. Beta particles can pass through water; 
however, thin aluminium is easily capable of stopping 
it. Lead or concrete are needed to stop X-rays, gamma
rays, and radio waves. Neutrons can only stopped by

5. Result 
      By summing up all the possible space experiences,

we realise that there will be competitive offerings, 
opening up a genuine market place which will ensure 
that service will improve, safety and reliability will 
increase, and prices will come down, exactly as has 
happened with aviation. 
 
6. Discussion  
     The research indicates that beta particles can be 
stopped by a few millimetres of aluminium. The steel 
plate sample is thicker and denser than the aluminium, 
so its likely to block out more cosmic rays than

so its likely to block out more cosmic rays than 
aluminium. But out of these gold foils have significant 
effect on the cosmic rays as they are thinner and denser. 
As we know cosmic rays can be influenced by the 
magnetic fields of the Earth and sun, it may also be 
possible to slightly alter its path using small metal 
magnets. 
 
7. Conclusions  
Basic research provides the required definitions for 
the understanding of radiation effects and for the

development of models useful for designing radiation 
hardened systems. Due to the increasing sensitivity of 
microelectronics to radiation and the increasing 
complexity of spacecraft systems, it is more difficult to 
completely avoid the risk of radiation effects on a 
system. The goal is to reduce such risk, and the only 
way to do so is by monitoring every parameter of the 
radiation environment. It would be helpful to know 
what energies and types of cosmic rays were being

detected because it would give insight into why the 
shield did not block significant amounts of radiation. 
The shields may need some variations in order to block 
harmful radiations coming from sun and cosmic rays. 
 
8. Future Aspect 
       In the future, thicker samples of steel, aluminium, 
and gold will be used. Stronger magnets will be tested 
to determine if magnetism is an effective deflection 
method in larger amounts. More investigation could also

be performed on other materials such as polyethylene 
because its high hydrogen content suggests it would be 
an effective shield.

1.1.1 Types of Orbit  
Now for a satellite there are different orbits that it 
can be placed in. The Orbits with respect to the earth are 
as follows: 
 
1.1.1.1. Low Earth Orbit  
The orbit taken by a satellite that is 200 – 1200 km 
from the Earth’s surface is called as the Low Earth Orbit 
(LEO).  LEO is often used for objects that we want to 
visit often such as the ISS.  LEO is most convenient for

inspection and maintenance of the object so placed in it. 
 
1.1.1.2. Middle Earth Orbit 
The orbit taken by a satellite that is 1200 to 35786 
km from the Earth’s surface is called as the Middle 
Earth Orbit (MEO). It is also sometimes called the 
Intermediate Circular Orbit. The most common use of 
satellites in this region are for communication, 
navigation, and for space science. 
 
1.1.1.3. Geosynchronous Orbit 
The orbit taken by a satellite that is at a distance of

around 36000 km (35786 km from sea level) away from 
the Earth’s surface is called the Geosynchronous Orbit 
and is so called as it has an orbital period of 23 hours 56 
minutes and 4 seconds. Satellites placed in this Orbit are 
majorly used for Satellite Television and other such 
communication that requires the satellite to be over a 
given region for the entirety of its orbit.

3.2 Selection of Orbit 
As the title states, the selected orbit to place the 
satellite will be the Low Earth Orbit (LEO).Some of the 
reasons that LEO has been chosen are as follows: 
 
1. The distance between the user and the satellite is 
comparatively less and therefore there is less path loss. 
 
2. Less Energy is expended to place the satellite in LEO 
and thus the overall cost of the project is economical. 
 
3. Radiation experienced by the satellite is less when

compared to higher altitudes. 
 
4. LEO orbit provides a higher bandwidth and less 
latency and is therefore suitable for data transfer from 
the satellite to the base station. 
 
5. Once the Satellite serves its lifetime it can be 
removed from space by natural disintegration by the 
Earth’s atmosphere on re-entry thus not contributing to 
the growing worry of increasing space debris.

Pluto was the “ninth planet” to be discovered in our solar system and quite a few controversies surround this dwarf 
planet. First discovered 86 years ago, the celestial body was christened Pluto and was coined as the ninth planet of 
solar system. Since then various other celestial bodies of similar masses and sizes were discovered and were 
collectively named the Kuiper Belt. Since the discovery of Eris the International Astronomical Union (IAU) formally

deﬁned the term planet thus moving Pluto to the dwarf planet category. Since its discovery scientists and astronomers 
alike have been curious towards the nature of this celestial body. The recent launch of the New Horizons spacecraft 
by NASA in 2006 took about nine years to ﬂy by Pluto. During its brief ﬂyby of Pluto it made detailed measurements 
of Pluto and its moons. Man ﬁrst set foot on the moon in the year 1969 and now preparations are under way for a

manned mission to Mars. A manned mission to Pluto would signify the freeing of humanity from its shackles, 
tethering us to our Solar System. This paper will focus on the possibility of a manned mission to Pluto, the method of 
achieving this and the resources required. A detailed case study is prepared on the topic describing past and present 
proposed methods, their drawbacks, resources and technology required. The paper will also look into the future of

this endeavour with the advancement in technology. A glance will also be thrown towards the moons of Pluto and the 
other bodies present in Kuiper belt describing their orbits, geology, atmosphere and surface compositions. The 
possibility of this mission will open new horizons extending our grasp on the understanding and workings of our 
universe and in local sense our solar system. 
 
Keywords: Pluto, Kuiper Belt, Unmanned, Orbit,

1. Introduction 
Robotic missions are much cheaper and may provide 
more scientific information, but they don't catch the 
public imagination in the same way, and they don't 
spread the human race into space, which I'm arguing 
should be our long-term strategy. “If the human race is 
to continue for another million years, we will have to 
boldly go where no one has gone before." ~ Stephen 
Hawking 
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 losing

its status as a planet. This move caused much 
controversy and debate. Contradictory believes of 
considering Pluto a full-fledged planet or not is an 
interesting discussion that made one thing certain: The 
object is shrouded in mystery, and we don't have a 
complete picture of what it would be like to live there. 
We've never been to anywhere like Pluto.  
Unmanned exploratory missions can collect data but 
they cannot detect weird microscopic life-forms that are

not in our database yet. At least not yet. They are not 
programmed to recognize what might be lurking below 
the surface of Charon, or beneath the icy murky seas of 
Pluto. Astronaut missions are expensive and riskier than

So in this paper, the propaganda is to explore the

about the major celestial figures in Pluto’s orbit and

2. Pluto  
Pluto is the largest known dwarf planet in the solar 
system and was once considered the ninth and most 
distant planet from the sun. Beyond the gas giant 
Neptune lies an entire region of space filled with icy 
bodies known as the Kuiper Belt, of which Pluto is the 
largest 
known 
member 
of. 
In 
2006, 
Pluto 
was reclassified as a dwarf planet, a change widely

considered as a demotion. This question of Pluto's 
celestial status attracted a lot of controversies and stirred 
a debate in the scientific community, and among the 
general public as well.  
Launched on January 19, 2006, NASA's New Horizons 
spacecraft flashed past Pluto on July 14, 2015. From 
Pluto’s unusual heart-shaped region to its extended 
atmosphere and intriguing moons, New Horizons has 
revealed a degree of diversity and complexity in the

Pluto system that few expected in the frigid outer 
reaches of the solar system. 
 
3.  Composition & Structure 
3.1 Atmospheric Composition - Nitrogen, methane. 
Observations by New Horizons reveals that 
atmosphere of Pluto extends as far as sixteen 
hundred kilometers (1,000 miles) above the 
surface of the dwarf planet. 
 
3.2 Magnetic Field - Although unknown about the 
existence of Pluto’s magnetic field, the slow 
rotation and small size of the dwarf planet

rotation and small size of the dwarf planet 
suggest it has little to no such field. 
 
3.3 Chemical Composition - Estimating a mixture 
of 30 percent water ice and 70 percent rock is 
quite probable. 
 
3.4 Internal Structure - Pluto probably has a rocky 
core enclosed within a mantle of water ice 
along with more exotic ices such as carbon 
monoxide, methane and nitrogen ice coating 
the entire surface. 
 
4. Orbit and Rotation 
Pluto's rotation is retrograde compared to the other

worlds of our solar systems. It spins from east to 
west. 
4.1 Average distance from the sun - 5,906,380,000 
kilometers (3,670,050,000 miles) which is 
39.482 times the distance of Earth. 
4.2 Perihelion (closest distance from the sun) - 
4,436,820,000 kilometers (2,756,902,000miles) 
which is 30.171 times the distance of Earth 
4.3 Aphelion (farthest approach to the sun) - 
7,375,930,000 kilometers (4,583,190,000miles) 
which is 48.481 times the distance of Earth

this 
mission

Making

successful, 
NASA's 
most 
impressive achievements till date coined a question – 
What Next? 
 
5. Sending Man to Pluto 
The next logical step for further expansion of our 
technically bounded horizons would be of a robotic 
Pluto lander followed by manned mission to Pluto. New 
Horizons is currently the fastest spacecraft that has ever 
left Earth. It crossed Jupiter’s orbit the very next year of 
its launch and had travelled nearly a million miles in a

day. Still it took about 9.5 years for the spacecraft to 
reach Pluto and its moons. Organizing a manned 
mission will require additional 10 years for their return 
back. Food, air, water, fuel, exercise and life in zero 
gravity for 20 years would make any team going 
incapable of living back on the Earth for a longer period 
of time after their return from the mission. In order to 
overcome that, time duration of the mission needs to be 
compensated.

compensated. 
The most advanced propulsion systems in our 
technological grasp today requires 10 to 15 years for 
delivering 1.6-kilogram (3.5 lbs.) spacecraft in Pluto’s 
orbit. The International Space Station (ISS) has been 
continuously orbiting around the Earth, manned, since 
Oct. 31, 2000. There is, of course, a wide difference 
between the ISS and a manned Pluto spacecraft 
including the lack of significant propulsion. The ISS has 
been resupplied and occupied by crews rotating from

Earth several times per annum for the past 14 years. 
Whereas, astronauts traveling to Pluto would be utterly 
isolated with self-contained life supporting systems. The 
longest period of a human spending time in space has 
been recorded of 437 days and no self-contained, closed 
biosphere has the capacity of holding human life for 
more than two years.  
The only known spacecraft propulsion technology 
that is capable of delivering a multihundred-ton manned

spacecraft to Pluto within a year has been laying around 
since 1950s and is titled Project Orion. The concept of 
this technology is to propel the spacecraft by exploding 
thousands of small nuclear bombs fixated behind it. 
Each detonation drives a "pusher plate" of the spacecraft 
by an enormous set of shock absorbers. The exhaust 
velocities created are 10s-100s of kilometres per second 
with millions of tons of thrust. The project essentially
worked out in 1960s was revisited by NASA in 2000

under the name of External Pulsed Plasma Propulsion. 
The Physicist from 1960s developed an advanced 
interplanetary configuration which was capable of 
delivering a 10,000-ton spacecraft to Saturn and return

back in three years. Such a spacecraft could not be 
launched directly from the Earth's surface due to its 
nuclear fallout. Instead, it could be constructed in the 
orbit of Earth, with the help of ISS and depart for Pluto 
from there. In a couple of years, the nuclear powered 
spacecraft would decelerate into orbit around Pluto 
while turning off its engines. Human carrying ship 
descending to Pluto's surface would use more 
conventional chemical rockets. Gravitational force on

Pluto’s Surface is about 1/12 of Earth's (half of the 
moon’s as well). Landing on the surface from a low 
orbit at an altitude of 100 kilometres (62 miles) will 
require half the Delta-V of a landing on the moon from 
the same height (i.e. Eight hundred meters per second 
versus seventeen hundred meter per second). 
6. Touching Down on Pluto  
 Landing on Pluto would present some unique 
challenges especially if the spacecraft is manned. 
Pluto’s surface has a thin atmosphere of methane,

nitrogen and carbon monoxide. The surface pressure of 
Pluto varies from 6.5 to 24 microbars about as thick as 
Earth's atmosphere 80 kilometres (50 miles) up. This is 
not enough to provide any useful aero-braking 
capability (like a parachute) but enough to require some 
kind of heat shield. 
An equipment to be considered for that to overcome is 
SpaceX's Dragon V2 capsule. It is probably a step in the 
right direction as it combines heat shield with

right direction as it combines heat shield with 
propulsive landing rockets. The Dragon V2 can store 
enough fuel for 300 meter per second Delta-V, so extra 
fuel tanks are needed in order to take off, land and 
rendezvous with the orbiting mother ship. The 
technology available seems feasible for the project. 
There might be other hazards to be considered. Surface 
of the Moon is made mostly of silicate rock. Whereas, 
Pluto is covered with ice. Not just water ice, but frozen

nitrogen, carbon monoxide and methane. On contact 
with extremely hot rocket exhaust at thousands of 
degrees, there's a real danger of the vaporization of the 
landing site. Some previous equipment’s are needed to 
be transported in order to create a stable landing surface 
for the first Pluto explorers. 
7. Future Scope of this Endeavor  
The time duration for the entire journey can be  
exhausting. And knowing no bounds to human minds,

the atmosphere inside the spacecraft can get homicidal. 
Psychological and biological factors are vital concern. 
The crew can be induced to hibernation, an alternative 
to the problems of survival making them easier to 
resolve. Hibernation is a kind of torpor, or reduced 
metabolism which can be induced by hypothermia. 
Unlike in cryogenics, the body will not actually freeze. 
A 10 degree drop in the temperature of body can 
reduces metabolic rate by 50 to 70 percent. Dormant

astronauts would be immobilized in their special 
hibernation capsules. They will not require pressurized 
living space or artificially generated gravity. In their 
coma induced state, astronauts would be regularly 
monitored automatically by the spacecraft’s computer, 
and fed intravenously. 
 
 
 
Fig 1- Scientists are hoping to induce an unconscious 
state in astronauts so that they can be stored in cold 
capsules for long space flights. 
 
Radiation is a major concern in deep-space travel.

Heavy shielding against radiation could be provided 
only to the crew’s sleep capsules and the large living 
areas of the ship are saved from this technological 
implement, saving a lot of weight and fuel. 
8. Kuiper Belt  
Beyond the gas giant Neptune lies the third zone of 
solar system, a region of space filled with icy bodies. 
This region is known as the Kuiper Belt, this chilly 
expanse in space holds trillions of mysterious objects 
that are remnants of the early solar system.

that are remnants of the early solar system. 
The Kuiper Belt is an elliptical plane in the later solar 
system spanning from thirty to fifty times Earth's 
distance from the sun, or 4.5 to 7.4 billion kilometres 
(2.5 to 4.5 billion miles). The belt appears similar to the 
asteroid belt found between Mars and Jupiter, although 
objects in the Kuiper Belt tend more towards icy in 
nature rather than rocky.

Pluto was the first truly recognized Kuiper Belt Object, 
although scientists didn't recognize it as such at that 
time. The existence of the belt could not be realized 
until scientists discovered a slowly moving, small world

in the outer region of our solar system in 1992 (Jane 
Luu and David Jewitt found the KBO, 1992QB1.). 
Other discoveries soon followed, and astronomers 
quickly realized that the region beyond Neptune was 
filled with icy rocks and tiny worlds. 
Sedna, about three-fourth of the size of Pluto, was 
discovered in 2004. It is so far away from the sun that it 
takes about 10,500 years to make one single orbit. 
Sedna is about 1,770 kilometers (1,100 miles) wide and

revolves around the sun on an eccentric orbit that ranges 
between 12.9 billion kilometers (8 billion miles) and 
135 billion kilometers (84 billion miles). 
On July 2005, astronomers announced the discovery of 
a large object in the Kuiper Belt thought to be even 
larger than Pluto, though subsequent observations 
denied the previous observations and it was found 
slightly smaller. Dubbed as Eris, it orbits the sun 
approximately once in every 580 years, traveling almost

a hundred times farther from the sun than Earth. Eris’s 
discovery disputed the problem of terming Pluto a full-
scale planet between the astronomers, and in 2006, Eris, 
Pluto, and the largest asteroid Ceres were classified as 
dwarf planets. Two more dwarf planets were discovered 
in

known

9. Moons of Pluto  
Pluto has five moons orbiting around: Charon, Nix, Styx, 
Kerberos and Hydra, where Charon being the closest

and Hydra being the most distant to Pluto. 
9.1 Charon - In 1978, astronomers discovered a 
very large moon nearly half the size of Pluto. 
This moon was called Charon. 
Being so similar in size unlike most of the other planets 
and their moons, Charon and Pluto formed a unique 
system. Both Pluto and Charon orbit a common point in 
space that lies in-between them, just like the orbits of 
binary star systems, for this reason, Pluto and Charon

are referred as double planet, a double dwarf planet or a 
binary system. Charon and Pluto orbit each other every 
6.387 days. 
The mass and volume of Charon allow the calculation of 
its density which is 1.702±0.021 g/cm from which it can 
be determined the slightly less dense internals of Charon 
than Pluto and thus Charon contains a larger proportion 
of ice relative to rock in its interior. 
 
Unlike Pluto’s surface, Charon's surface appears to be

dominated by less volatile water ice. In 2007, 
observations made by the Gemini Observatory of 
patches of water crystals and ammonia hydrates on the 
surface 
of 
Charon 
suggested 
the 
presence 
of 
active cryogeysers and cryovolcanoes.

9.2 Nix- Nix is a natural satellite of Pluto. It was 
discovered along with Hydra (Pluto's outermost 
satellite) in June 2005.

satellite) in June 2005. 
 
Nix follows a circular orbit in the same plane 
as Charon. Its orbital period of 24.9 days. It is in a 
3:2 orbital resonances with Hydra, and a 9:11 
resonance with Styx (the ratios represent numbers 
of orbits that are completed per unit time; the 
period ratios are the inverses). Nix has been 
measured to be 54 by 41 by 36 kilometres (33.6 mi 
× 25.5 mi × 22.4 mi) in diameter, indicating a very 
elongated shape, and a very high geometric albedo.

9.3  Styx- Styx is a small natural satellite of                     
Pluto whose 
discovery 
was

Styx is very irregularly shaped, measuring 5 by 7

formed from the debris lofted by a collision, which 
could have led to losses of the more volatile ices, 
such as those of nitrogen and methane, in the 
composition of the impactors. The process is

composition of the impactors. The process is

Styx orbits the Pluto–Charon barycentre at a 
distance of 42,656 km, putting it between the orbits 
of Charon and Nix.

Kerberos has a double-lobed shape and is

In the last 5 decades, the environment around the earth has gone from a debris free space to a zone clustered with 
man-made objects. With the spread of technical knowledge of launching a satellite around the world, even more 
nations are getting involved in the space launch sector and with the increasing launches, the enormous problem of 
space debris has come up. Space debris has substantially increased the threats to the launch activities and all the

orbiting satellites are now in danger of an unexpected collision at any point of time. There are currently more than 
thousand active satellites orbiting the earth and along with them there are millions of space debris fragments going at 
speeds of several kilometres per seconds. Space debris is a threat to any spacecraft irrespective of the orbit. Though 
the quantity of space debris differs in different orbits, with the most concentration in the Low Earth Orbit and least in

the High Earth Orbit. Low Earth Orbit have reached to the critical density of unwanted fragments and parts. 
Satellites now face many problems that range from damages to even destabilization of their orbit. These problems 
must be resolved in next few years or it will become very difficult to launch satellites in the low earth orbit in the 
coming years. The accumulation of the space debris presents a real threat to productive use of space. This paper

seeks to explore the history of space debris and also list the problems that are now faced by any new satellites that 
are deployed in the low earth orbit. The orbital calculations for any new satellite that is launched today have become 
very complex and sometimes trajectory corrections have to be done in orbit to avoid a certain piece of junk. This 
paper explores all these challenges and explains some of the consequences if proper measures are not undertaken to

curb space debris. As case study, a typical university Nano satellite at 700km of altitude will be analyses in terms of 
space debris mitigation.

were already circulating below an altitude of 200 km 
(125 miles). These pieces might be small but this space 
junk is usually travelling at a relative speeds of 50,000 
kmph or even more with huge kinetic energy capable of 
creating catastrophic damage. Although, the outer space 
is often considered to be an empty, desolated place, the

region surrounding the Earth swarms with thousands 
and millions of pieces, of debris created by our kind that 
can lead to potential hazards for their artificially 
functioning neighbours.

6. Mitigation 
Since we are the only ones creating the space debris, so 
we are the only ones to take responsibilities to prevent 
it. We need to take some actions towards the future of 
space exploration. In 2002, the Inter-Agency Debris

Coordination Committee published the "IADC Space 
Debris Mitigation Guidelines," and presented these to 
the UNCOPUOS Scientific & Technical Subcommittee 
(STSC), where they served as a baseline for the "UN 
Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines." In 2007 these 
guidelines were approved by the 63 STSC member 
nations as voluntary high-level mitigation measures. 
Since the mid-1990s, space agencies in Europe have 
developed more technically oriented guidelines as a

"European Code of Conduct," which was signed by 
ASI, UKSA, CNES, DLR and ESA in 2006. 
The core elements of this Code of Conduct are in line 
with the IADC and UN guidelines. In order to tailor the 
Code of Conduct to the needs of ESA projects, ESA has 
developed its own "Requirements on Space Debris 
Mitigation for Agency Projects". These instructions 
came into force on 1 April 2008. They are applicable to 
all future procurements of space systems (launchers,

satellites and inhabited objects).

2. The Fundamentals of Spaceports 
 
Basically, a spaceport can be defined as an 
installation that can be used to launch rockets and other 
spacecraft into space. The word spaceport is derived

from the word airport and it symbolizes the whole 
infrastructure and the installation required to launch 
rockets into space. The existing spaceports today are 
called launch sites and they are owned and operated by 
governments. 
 
2.1 Existing Spaceports (Launch Sites) 
 
There are several existing spaceports in operation 
today by the USA, Russia, France, China and India. 
Cape Kennedy in USA is perhaps the most famous 
spaceport as majority of launches in the world are

conducted from there and it was also home to the 
famous Space Shuttle launches. It was named after the 
then President John F. Kennedy who had the vision of 
landing on the Moon. It was made ready for space 
launches in 1950 which marks its first launch, lifting off 
the Bumper 8 rocket on July 24. Ever since then Cape 
Kennedy has been home to more than 3000 rockets 
now. It has been a witness to the success of NASA’s 
Mercury and Gemini missions, all the Apollo flights

using Saturn 1 and Skylab, the Mars exploration rovers, 
Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter and all the benchmarks 
 
of excellence and teamwork that the country has been 
able to achieve at this spaceport. Initially until the sixth 
Bumper series rocket, the White Sands at New Mexico 
had been the launch site, where the war missiles had 
been launching. With the need to achieve longer range 
rockets, Span Starr, the then chief of Applied Physics at

the Kennedy Space Centre realized the potential of Cape 
Kennedy. It attracted the attention because of two prime 
reasons: i) it is much closer to the equator, being 28 
degrees latitude above the equator (relatively closer than 
the other US locations). This is a benefit since the 
velocity of the Earth’s rotation is much greater at the 
equator, hence saving the rocket on fuel consumption. 
The eastward rotation of the Earth combined with an 
eastward directed launch velocity of the rocket

eastward directed launch velocity of the rocket 
accelerates the travel relieving the propulsion system; ii) 
It is near the east coast of the geography, close to the 
island with a much sparsely populated area. This assures 
safety to the relatively habited land and also safety 
during accidents as the malfunction will end up crashing 
into the waters of the island itself. This region is prone 
to precipitation, wind and lightening, despite which it is

NASA’s prime choice. This is because it is relatively 
safer as compared to the other hurricane prone or 
cyclone prone areas in the US. The above two major 
aspects more than compensate for reasons as to why 
Cape Kennedy is the best site to open America’s 
windows to the cosmos. It is declared as the Long 
Range Proving Ground. 
 
The Russians use the Baikonur Facility to launch 
their rockets. The lands of Baikonur have seen birth of 
the space missions and the subsequent milestones that

count as “first ever” in space history; first space launch-
Sputnik 1 in 1954, first man in space , first moon 
mission , first female in space, first crewed mission in 
space. Today the site marks the launches of all the 
Soyuz rockets and the Russian cosmonauts to the ISS. 
The area is essentially remote thus reducing the risk to 
human population. The spaceport is located on a desert 
steppe east of the Aral Sea. It is an area of harsh climate

and may not show geographical inclinations leading to 
its set up. However, existence of an already established 
facility to transport material for manufacture and rockets 
themselves motivated its construction in 1955. The area 
ensures reachable control by Russia and is capable to 
launch larger boosters. 
 
France launches its rockets from Guiana which is 
capable of launching a variable range of rockets such as 
the heavy-lift Ariane 5, medium size Soyuz and

the heavy-lift Ariane 5, medium size Soyuz and 
lightweight Vega. It is operational since 1968. 
Geographically, this site holds the most potential. It is 
very close to the equator, a little over 5 degrees which is 
advantageous for saving fuel and money just as Cape 
Kennedy, except it is comparatively much closer. Thus, 
it is cost effective and saves fuel. Moreover, it is highly 
remote. Its geographical location is so ideal that it is
